results.brief_description:

results.title: 10 Easy ways to lose your job
results.creator_credit: Tom Colello, Donna Boundy and Reelizations
results.brief_description: Short vignettes illustrate the most common mistakes young people make when they are new to the workforce. These include: calling into work sick at the last minute, chronic lateness, not following instructions and less devious forms of stealing such as taking goods and services from the store or office. There is also an emphasis on attitude and how this affects customer service.

results.title: 100 years of Australian football
results.creator_credit: David Barham, Neil Kearney, Australian Football League, Seven Network Limited (Australia) and Visual Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: For lovers of the great game of Australian Rules Football, this documentary highlights the game’s magnificent 100 year history. Using archival footage and interviews, the legends of the game including the great Jack Dyer and Mr. Football himself, Ted Whitten are featured together with many past and present heroes.

results.title: Forests and wood
results.creator_credit: Justin Milne, Lesley Hammond, New Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Pinus radiata is shown to be a reliable and versatile source of timber. The life cycle of the pine is traced from the propagation through planting to initial thinning and clear felling. The milling process is then examined along with kiln drying and treatment with protective chemicals. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Siege of Pinchgut
results.creator_credit: Harry Watt, Sir Michael Balcon and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description: Made in Australia by Ealing Studios, this film is concerned with the escape from prison of a man who claims he has been unjustly incarcerated. He escapes and lands on Pinchgut Island in Sydney Harbour, occupies a disused arsenal and defies a police seige by taking the caretaker and his family hostage. Stars Aldo Ray and Heather Sears with Richard Vernon, Grant Taylor and Kenneth Warren. Screenplay by Harry Watt and Jon Cleary.

results.title: Looks and smiles
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Irving Teitelbaum, Black Lion Films and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: This film by Ken Loach, the Director of “Cathy come home”, “Family life and “Kes”, takes a bleak but compassionate look at working-class life in contemporary Britain. It is set in Industrialized Sheffield and while not an attack on the system, the film implicity condemns the system’s failure to cope with economic fluctuations. Script by Barry Hines.

results.title: The Sound collector
results.creator_credit: Lynn Smith, David Verrall, Ishu Patel and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The Sound Collector, an animation film that uses a combination of collage, paper cut-outs and colored inks on glass, features Leonard, a six-year-old with an unusual hobby. He collects sounds. Transforming household noises around him into exciting fantasies, he creates an adventure story for his scornful older brother in which knights in armor chase away monsters and perform other daring deeds. This film that will entertain young and old alike lends itself to a variety of classroom uses, to encourage creativity in children, and to stimulate discussion on topics such as individuality, family relationships, and imagination.

results.title: Autobiography of a princess
results.creator_credit: James Ivory, Ismail Merchant and Merchant Ivory Productions
results.brief_description: An Indian rajah’s past is recalled by his exiled daughter (Madhur Jaffrey) and his ageing tutor (James Mason), interspersed with old movies from the rajah’s archives. An absorbing character study which also reveals something of the complexities and contradictions of India and the role of the British in India. Written by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Water management
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Peter Dimond and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Comic dramatisation is used to stress the importance of water conservation. Studies Adelaide’s water supply system to explain how and why water should be conserved. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Let there be light
results.creator_credit: John Huston and Department of Defense
results.brief_description: Produced by the American Department of Defence and banned for 35 years, this documentary deals with the treatment of soldiers suffering from war-induced psychotic and psychosomatic disorders. The camera records a wide range of emotional disabilities among the returning World War II veterans at Mason General Hospital at Long Island. Looks at the various methods of treatment which include hypnosis and truth-inducing drugs. The original purpose of the film was to convince the public, employers in particular, that soldiers suffering from neuro-psychiatric damage could be rehabilitated and resume civilian life. After seeing the finished product, the War Department withdrew the film for various reasons among them the invasion of the patients’ privacy and the fear that it would scare off potential recruit. Narrated by Walter Huston. Cinematography by Stanley Cortez.
